en_chiesapioggia.title: Titolo mancante
en_chiesapioggia.main_text:
The Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia , whose full name is Church of Santa Maria della Pioggia and San Bartolomeo di Reno, is located at the intersection of Via Galliera and Via Riva di Reno in Bologna.

Here are some key information:

  • Origin: It was originally known as the Church of San Bartolomeo di Reno and dates back to the 13th century as an Oratory.

  • Name: The nickname "Madonna della Pioggia" (Our Lady of the Rain) derives from an event in 1561, when a procession carrying the statue of the Madonna was associated with the end of a severe drought that had struck Bologna, bringing beneficial rains. Following this miraculous event, it was dedicated to the Saint and the Madonna.

  • Structure and Works: The church, which has undergone several renovations over the centuries, features a fa√ßade preceded by a portico with three arches. It houses works of art by artists such as Agostino Carracci, Francesco Monti, Ludovico Mattioli (his fresco Landscape with Saint Bartholomew is located on the eighteenth-century staircase leading to the oratory), and a terracotta sculpture by Alfonso Lombardi ( Saint Bartholomew ).

  • Interior: The interior has a single nave with three side chapels and features a frescoed barrel vault.

  • Statue: It houses the 13th-century statue of the Madonna della Provvidenza (also known as the Madonna della Pioggia), placed to the left of the main altar and donated in 1435 by the Bolognese Senate.

History:



The church, originally dedicated to Saint Bartholomew, houses a painting of the Madonna and Child, attributed to the 15th-century Bolognese painter Michele di Matteo. The panel has been considered miraculous since its discovery; in fact, it was found completely intact under the rubble of a building destroyed by fire. Other miracles are attributed to the panel, such as restoring sight to a blind man and helping the people of Bologna during a long drought in the 16th century (hence the dedication to the Madonna della Pioggia).



Sanctuary:



Initially (1449) the miraculous image was placed on the first floor of the oratory. A few centuries later (1732) the church was rebuilt and the painting was placed in the niche above the altar. In the same year the procession was celebrated and was attended by Cardinal Lambertini, the future Pope Benedict XIV.



The building's fa√ßade features a tall colonnaded portico. The interior has a single nave covered by a barrel vault decorated with frescoes, and four modest-sized chapels on the sides. The decorations adorning both the chapels and the main altar are the result of the 1929-31 restoration.



The first chapel on the left houses a painting by the Bolognese painter and engraver Agostino Carracci, depicting the Adoration of the Shepherds. Unfortunately, the work was damaged in a fire during World War II. In the opposite chapel, there is a 16th-century painting attributed to Lorenzo Sabbatini depicting the Madonna and Child Enthroned between Saints Catherine and Lucy.



The Sanctuary also houses the nursing robe that belonged to Saint Camillus de Lellis, who founded the Camillian Order in 1575. To the left of the main altar is the 13th-century statue of Our Lady of Providence, also known as Our Lady of the Serraglio.

Public and institutional sources on the history and places of worship in Bologna:

  • Official Tourism and Culture Websites: such as Bologna Welcome and BolognaBO , which provide details on the location, opening hours, and history of the church.

  • Online Encyclopedias and Historical Archives: such as Wikipedia and Bologna Online/Biblioteca Salaborsa , which offer insights into the 13th-century origins, the reconstruction, the miracle of the rain of 1561 that gave the Sanctuary its name, and the list of works of art housed there (such as those by Agostino Carracci, Francesco Monti, Ludovico Mattioli and Alfonso Lombardi).

  • Art Guides and Portals: which confirm the full names (Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia, Church of Santa Maria della Pioggia and of San Bartolomeo di Reno) and the most important works of art.

These sources agree on key information regarding the location (at the intersection of Via Galliera and Via Riva di Reno), the original name (San Bartolomeo di Reno) and the double dedication following the miracle of the rain.

The Church of San Benedetto in Bologna, located in Via Indipendenza, has a long and complex history:

  • Origins: Its origins date back to the 13th century (some documents mention it as a parish as early as 1202). It was initially located just outside Bologna's second city walls.

  • 17th-century reconstruction: It was completely rebuilt in 1606 based on a design by Giovanni Battista Ballerini . At that time, it was officiated by the Minim Friars of San Francesco di Paola (known as "paolotti"), to whom it had been assigned in 1529.

  • Original Orientation: Until the end of the nineteenth century, the church overlooked Via Galliera , where the ancient fa√ßade (later redone in 1932) flanked by the bell tower is still visible today.

  • The opening of Via Indipendenza: The major transformation took place in 1892 with the opening of the new Via dell'Indipendenza . To adapt to the new layout and the new road, the orientation of the church was reversed : the apse became the new fa√ßade, which was rebuilt with the addition of a portico.

  • Interior: Despite the external transformations, the interior preserves important works by artists who were protagonists of the Bolognese Mannerism and Baroque periods, including paintings by Giacomo Cavedoni , Alessandro Tiarini and Lucio Massari .

In short, the current appearance of the church is the result of the seventeenth-century reconstruction and the radical reorientation at the end of the nineteenth century, when it was "turned" to face the modern Via Indipendenza.

Historical Sources for the Church of San Benedetto

  1. Sources of Toponymy and Urban History of Bologna:

    • Archives and Studies on the History of Via Indipendenza: These documents (often linked to the State Archives or the Archiginnasio Library) are crucial for precisely dating the great transformation of 1892 , the year in which the church was "turned" and the facade reoriented to face the newly created Via Indipendenza.

    • Studies on the Bolognese Churches: Academic texts and monographs which attest to their origins in the 13th century and the subsequent 17th century reconstruction (dated 1606 ), specifying the role of the architect Giovanni Battista Ballerini .

  2. Sources of the History of Art and Architecture of Bologna:

    • Art Guides and Catalogs: For a list of the interior works and artists. These sources confirm the presence of paintings by Baroque and Mannerist masters, such as Giacomo Cavedoni , Alessandro Tiarini , and Lucio Massari .

    • Texts on Religious Complexes: To identify the Order that managed it, namely the Minim Friars of San Francesco di Paola (the "Paolotti").

  3. Institutional Sites and Cultural Portals (Web):

    • Official Tourism and Culture Portals of the Municipality of Bologna (e.g. Bologna Welcome or History and Memory of Bologna ): These sites summarize and validate key historical data (13th century, 17th-century reconstruction, late 19th-century reorientation) for public use.

In summary, the information comes from a concordance of data present in historical archives, art history studies, and institutional sources that trace the evolution of this important Bolognese place of worship.

en_graziaxx.title: Titolo mancante
en_graziaxx.main_text:
The plague that struck Bologna in 1630 was a dramatic event, part of a larger epidemic that devastated Northern Italy, also known as the Manzonian plague.

Here are the main points:

Spread : The epidemic was brought to Bologna in May 1630 by Landsknecht soldiers, who had arrived to besiege Mantua during the War of the Mantuan Succession.
Despite the efforts of Cardinal Legate Bernardino Spada and the Bolognese Senate to keep the contagion outside the walls, the disease spread.

Casualties : It was a catastrophic event for the city's demographics. In the city, 13,398 victims were recorded between May and December 1630, out of a population of approximately 61,559 inhabitants in the urban center.
In the surrounding countryside, the victims numbered approximately 16,300. In total, it is estimated that Bologna and its surrounding countryside lost approximately 40,000 people.

Emergency management : The fight against the epidemic was directed by Cardinal Bernardino Spada, who availed himself of the work of the Camillian religious to assist the plague victims. <
Lazarettos were set up outside Porta Santo Stefano and in Castelfranco.

Consequences : The city, already suffering from the famines of the early century, lost nearly half its population. The epidemic had serious social consequences.

Art and Memory : In memory and thanksgiving for the end of the plague, the famous Plague Altarpiece (or "Altarpiece of the Virgin and the patron saints of Bologna who intercede for the city") was commissioned from Guido Reni in 1630. A precious votive canopy was also created.

Primary Sources (Originals of the time):

  1. Official and Administrative Documentation:

    • Proclamations and Decrees of the Assunteria di Sanit√† and the Bolognese Senate (starting in 1628, regarding the management of the contagion, the measures adopted, and the organization of services). Most of these documents are preserved in the State Archives of Bologna .

    • Death and Burial Registers (for data on victims, mortality peaks and mass graves).

    • Expenditure Statements (for the sums allocated to the poor, to medical police, to the emptying of houses and to the management of lazarettos).

    • Contemporary chronicles and official reports (for example, the report by Pietro Moratti ‚Äì Account of the orders and provisions made in the Lazaretti in Bologna and its County during the contagion of the Year 1630 ).

  2. Artistic and Votive Testimonies:

    • The Plague Altarpiece by Guido Reni (1630): direct testimony of civic devotion and religious devotion.

    • The votive canopy of 1634 (used in thanksgiving processions).

    • Paintings and Ex-Votos (such as the anonymous Bolognese painting on the plague in Via San Mamolo, often cited in secondary sources).

Secondary Sources (Subsequent Historical Studies):

  1. Specific historical studies on Bologna and the plague of 1630:

    • Historical demography studies that have elaborated data on deaths and population (e.g. Marco Poli , author of studies on epidemics in Bologna, or older demographic studies such as those of PL Da Gatteo and A. Brighetti ).

    • Monographs and essays that reconstruct the spread, healthcare management (the role of Cardinal Bernardino Spada and the Camillians ), and the social consequences of the epidemic.

  2. General Historical Context:

    • The sources that deal with the War of Succession of Mantua and the passage of the Landsknechts , responsible for the spread of the contagion throughout Northern Italy (as also mentioned in Alessandro Manzoni's The Betrothed , which although not a primary historical source for Bologna, testifies to the general context of the 1630 epidemic in Northern Italy)

en_lastre.title: Titolo mancante

In Bologna, you'll find sandstone slabs in various streets of the historic center that aren't just decorative, but also have a very interesting historical significance. These are the city's oldest house numbers. They were introduced in the late 18th century, when Bologna was under Napoleonic rule, to better organize the postal service and city administration.

Before then, houses didn't have numbers, and people sometimes oriented themselves by the description of the facade or the name of the family who lived there. The sandstone tiles, which you still find today, are a testament to this change. Many of those you see are terracotta and were made over the centuries, sometimes replacing the original ones. While terracotta tiles were easier to mass-produce, the engraving on the stone was a handcrafted work that demonstrates the importance and durability these urban landmarks were intended to provide.

The presence of these sandstone numbers is a tangible testimony to the evolution of the city and the traditional materials used over the centuries.

At number 11 on Via Tanari Vecchia we find a sandstone plaque bearing the number 1202 (an even number), while the current number is 11 (an odd number), being on the right in the direction of increasing numbers, as required by current toponymic regulations.

The Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia and of San Bartolomeo di Reno (Via Riva di Reno, 124, corner of Via Galliera) in Bologna, houses the "Landscape with Bartolomeo" which is a work by the Bolognese painter Ludovico Mattioli .

The work mentioned is located along the staircase leading to the upper rooms of the church and is not a painting by Annibale, as it is erroneously attributed to him, but by one of his successors from the Bolognese school.

  • Artist: Ludovico Mattioli (1662-1747)

  • Title (probable): Landscape with Saint Bartholomew

  • Location: Staircase of the Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia and San Bartolomeo di Reno, Bologna.

  • Dating: 18th century.

Historical and Artistic Context:

  • Landscape in the 18th Century: Although Annibale Carracci pioneered the "ideal landscape" in the 17th century, Ludovico Mattioli worked in a later era, the 18th century, when the landscape genre was fully developed and independent. Mattioli, a Bolognese artist active between the late 17th and early 18th centuries, was known not only for his canvases but also as an engraver and landscape painter .

  • Style: His landscapes are typical of the late Baroque and Rococo style. Unlike Annibale's solemn and "heroic" nature, Mattioli's works present a more painterly , airy , and less structured style, with a predilection for atmosphere and light effects.

  • The Church: The Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia (or San Bartolomeo di Reno) has undergone numerous renovations over the centuries. The current church is mostly from the 18th century (rebuilt according to a design attributed to Alfonso Torreggiani), and works such as that by Mattioli fit into this 18th-century decorative context.

  • Iconography: The inclusion of St. Bartholomew, the martyred apostle, serves as a reference to the ancient dedication of the church and the adjoining hospice.

en_pugliole.title: Titolo mancante
en_pugliole.main_text:
There was a street in Bologna called Pugliole di San Bernardino . This street disappeared following the urban planning interventions of the 1930s which led to the creation of Via Guglielmo Marconi (then Via Roma).

The "Pugliole di San Bernardino" took their name from the Monastery or Convent of San Bernardino which was located in the area of the current Piazza dei Martiri 1943-1945. The street branched off from Borgo Polese (the current Via Polese) and wound its way up to Via del Porto, partly following the current route of Via Marconi.

The term "Pugliola" (or, in the plural, "Pugliole") is an ancient term in Bolognese toponymy. It refers to an alley, a narrow street, or a small group of houses. It generally indicated a small road or a secondary residential area, often resulting from an ancient subdivision of the urban fabric.

Many streets and alleys in Bologna, such as "Pugliole di San Bernardino" or "Pugliole dello Spirito Santo," were named after nearby churches or monasteries, combining the name of the religious institution with the term "pugliola" to indicate the adjacent alley.

  • Collocazione: Scalinata del Santuario della Madonna della Pioggia e di San Bartolomeo di Reno, Bologna.

  • Datazione: XVIII secolo.

Contesto Storico e Artistico:

  • Il Paesaggio nel '700: Sebbene Annibale Carracci sia stato il pioniere del "paesaggio ideale" nel Seicento, Ludovico Mattioli opera in un'epoca successiva, il Settecento, in cui il genere paesaggistico era ormai pienamente sviluppato e autonomo. Mattioli, un artista bolognese attivo tra la fine del Seicento e l'inizio del Settecento, era noto non solo per le sue tele ma anche come incisore e pittore paesaggista.

  • Lo Stile: I suoi paesaggi sono tipici del gusto tardo-barocco e rococ√≤. A differenza della solenne e "eroica" natura di Annibale, le opere di Mattioli presentano uno stile pi√π pittorico, arioso e meno strutturato, con una predilezione per l'atmosfera e gli effetti luminosi.

  • La Chiesa: Il Santuario della Madonna della Pioggia (o San Bartolomeo di Reno) ha subito numerosi rifacimenti nel corso dei secoli. La chiesa attuale √® prevalentemente del Settecento (ricostruita su progetto attribuito ad Alfonso Torreggiani), e le opere come quella di Mattioli si inseriscono in questo contesto decorativo settecentesco.

  • Iconografia: L'inserimento di San Bartolomeo, l'apostolo martirizzato, funge da riferimento all'antica dedicazione della chiesa e dell'annesso ospizio.
